Authors:
Barbara J Crandall-Stotler, Laura Lowe Forrest, Raymond E
Stotler
Title:
A phylogeny of Fossombroniaceae based on three chloroplast
loci
Keywords:
Fossombronia, Austrofossombronia, rbcL, rps4, trnL,
phylogeny, ancestral state reconstructions, spore wall architecture
Abstract:
As currently delimited, Fossombroniaceae includes only
Fossombronia, the most speciose genus of the Pelliidae or simple
thalloid I clade. Limited sampling in liverwort-wide phylogenies has
consistently resolved the family as a monophyletic lineage of the
Pelliidae, intermediate in position between the clades comprising the
Pelliales and Pallaviciniales. Phylogenetic structure within the family
and patterns of character evolution have, however, not been addressed.
Since gametophytes of Fossombronia are typically fragile and ephemeral,
systematic inferences of species level diversity and relationships have
depended primarily on characters of spore wall architecture and sexual
strategy, although their reliability as informative characters has not
been tested. In this study, maximum parsimony, maximum likelihood and
Bayesian inference techniques are used to infer the phylogenetic
relationships of 30 accessions of Fossombronia from three chloroplast
loci, rbcL, rps4 and trnL. Three major clades are resolved within the
genus, one comprising most of the taxa having reticulate spores and a
second, most of the taxa having lamellate spores. The geographically
widespread species F. foveolata and F. pusilla are paraphyletic. Dioicy
is reconstructed as ancestral for the genus. Neither spore wall
architecture nor caulocalyx morphology consistently predicts the
phylogenetic position of an accession
